awd_titl_txt: The Virginia Mathematics Specialist Initiative: An Online Program to Prepare K-8 Mathematics Teacher Leaders for High-Need School Districts
awd_abstract_narration:
This Track 3: Master Teaching Fellowships project, The Virginia Mathematics Specialist Initiative: An Online Program to Prepare K-8 Mathematics Teacher Leaders for High-Need School Districts, will prepare 20 K-8 mathematics teachers to be mathematics teacher leaders in high-need school districts throughout Virginia. In addition to preparing 20 new mathematics teacher leaders for partnering school districts throughout Virginia, the project will: (1) help retain K-8 mathematics teachers in the partnering districts due to the availability of daily in-school professional development and (2) develop a sustainable, rigorous, interactive online program for preparing mathematics teacher leaders that will be accessible to teachers in Virginia and in other states across the country. Research has shown that preparing and deploying mathematics specialists is an effective way to provide professional development for K-8 teachers of mathematics and ultimately increase student achievement. The project's 20 mathematics teacher leaders will provide ongoing, professional development for K-8 teachers to help them develop a deep understanding of the mathematics content and effective pedagogical strategies needed to help students understand mathematics and make connections to other STEM disciplines.

This Noyce Master Teaching Fellowships project is a collaboration between Virginia Commonwealth University, the MathScience Innovation Center, the Virginia Mathematics and Science Coalition, and 20 high-need school districts across Virginia. This innovative project will advance the research of preparing and implementing mathematics teacher leaders in K-8  schools throughout Virginia by: (1) advancing knowledge about providing online professional development for teacher leaders and developing a framework for analyzing online professional development programs; (2) producing a highly effective online mathematics specialist preparation program that will be ready for future cohorts of teachers from districts inside and outside of Virginia and inform others interested in developing online professional development programs; (3) producing an online mentoring program for mathematics teacher leaders in high-need school districts that will help teacher leaders be successful in their early years and inform others interested in developing online mentorship programs; and (4) collaborating with high-need school districts in Virginia, many of which have not been part of previous efforts to prepare and implement mathematics specialists.

por.por_cntn:
A preexisting Masters program to prepare teachers to be mathematics specialists was redesigned as a fully online program to reach teachers across Virginia. In collaboration with our partner school districts, we recruited teachers who committed to completing the program and then serving as mathematics teacher leaders in their respective school systems. During the five-year grant cycle, twenty teachers graduated with a Masters degree in mathematics teacher leadership, satisfied all requirements for the mathematics specialist endorsement to their teaching license, and served for three years as mathematics teacher leaders in their districts.

Participants completed six mathematics content courses: Number and Operations, Rational Numbers and Proportional Reasoning, Geometry and Measurement, Probability and Statistics, Algebra and Functions I, and Algebra and Functions II. They also completed three education/leadership courses collectively focused on effective mathematics instruction, mathematics coaching, and activities commonly undertaken by mathematics specialists and mathematics teacher leaders. The program also included two semester capstone experience in the form of a school-based action research project. 

The preparation program employed a modified flipped classroom model. We designed each course to use a variety of tools for online learning to help facilitate participant collaboration and the sharing of ideas and, at the same time, maintain the rigorous content and interactive nature of the activities and assignments in the courses which is has been a hallmark of our nationally recognized mathematics specialist preparation program since its inception. The courses help participants develop a deep understanding of the mathematics content and provide opportunities for participants to develop the leadership skills for working with classroom teachers. Each of the courses featured structured small group discussions, frequently based upon case studies that are part of the Developing Mathematical Ideas professional development materials that delve into children's mathematical thinking. Other discussions were centered on mathematics problems assigned to the participants to explore and solve.

This program provided professional development for school building and district administrators in the form of a one-day workshop to prepare for having a mathematics teacher leader as part of their educational team. The program also included a two-year Mathematics Teacher Leadership Mentoring program for participants.  This monthly online program was facilitated by two experienced K-8 mathematics specialists and provided a forum for participants to discuss the challenges and successes of mathematics teacher leadership.

After successful completion of the preparation program, the 20 participants served in different types of leadership roles in their school districts including: (1) grade or vertical mathematics team leader, (2) organizer and facilitator for school or district wide mathematics professional development, (3) mathematics coach for teachers in a school or district, or (4) mathematics curriculum developer and organizer for elementary or middle grades. In these roles, they provided mathematics-focused leadership in a variety of ways including (a) collaborating with individual teachers through co-planning, co-teaching, and coaching, (b) assisting administrative and instructional staff in interpreting data and designing approaches to improve student achievement and instruction, (c) promoting teachers? delivery and understanding of the school curriculum through collaborative long-range and short-range planning, (d) facilitating mathematics professional learning communities for groups of teachers, (e) facilitating mathematics book studies and Lesson Study with groups of teachers, and (f) working with parents/guardians and community leaders to foster continuing home/school/community partnerships focused on students? learning of mathematics. Many program participants also provided leadership at a state level by making presentations at the Virginia Council of Mathematics Specialists and the Virginia Council of Teachers of Mathematics annual conferences and co-leading professional development for mathematics teachers in various regions in Virginia including a highly successful series of book talks featuring the NCTM Catalyzing Change books for teachers in various districts across the state.

A major outcome of this project was a special issue of the Journal of Mathematics and Science: Collaborative Explorations (https://scholarscompass.vcu.edu/jmsce_vamsc/vol17/iss1/) which features articles that describe (a) the online components of the preparation and mentoring programs, (b) the mentoring and support of teachers preparing to serve as mathematics teacher leaders, and (c) the subsequent service of mathematics specialists in leadership roles. The papers in this special issue were co-authored by author teams comprised of this project?s participants, preparation program faculty, and practicing mathematics specialists or school administrators. 

Through this project, we transitioned an existing in-person professional development program into a highly successful, interactive, and engaging online program to prepare mathematics teacher leaders that aligns with best practices for online instruction and teacher professional development. The program prepared twenty knowledgeable, skilled leaders for high-needs partner school districts. More information about this project can be found in the journal issue described above.
